@philtomson The problem is more for the kernel code. OpenCL uses C as a language for its kernels and MXNet uses C++ for CUDA and CPU kernels and is able to generate both from the same template, which is nice because you don't need to support 2 or 3 different versions of things.
i created an issue to discuss it #625
i created an issue to discuss it #625
Can we put learning rate in kvstore and synchronize it?

currently it only syncs once when call `kvstore.set_optimizer(optm)`. syncing later is nontrivial in a full async updating, some nodes may fast while others may slow, especially, any worker may die at any moment if running on the ec2 spot instance
This will result in different learning rate for each layer right?
With async sgd, each thread push their own grad update on their own weight, I think they should each increment num_updates by one.

no if set num_update = "the maximal number of updates applied to a weight", so every layer share the same upper bound. we can support defining a scheduler for each layer, but it seems over-engineering.

For me the concerns is consistency and flexibility. I think we shouldn't move to far away from prior tech with our  definitions. I think the most flexible thing is to separate it into regularization, magnitude and distribution. That also gets rid of the naming issue and as the documentation we can just describe how to get traditional variants of `Xavier` or `MSR&A`. I can implement my idea in `MXNet.jl` and we can then discuss which one is the better way.

@vchuravy I agree currently everyone is using their own way to name it which is a mass. For name `kaiming` comes from cxxnet and I just want to follow cxxnet way but not caffe way. I just changed the default magnitude and I suggest to use in this way first then we can discuss a better way then refactor.
Take a look ar https://github.com/vchuravy/MXNet.jl/commit/fc6b4ed990c4d43c318077d73a6d6984444981a4 and It also allows to side-step the naming issue.

This is a great direction and I think this should be merged, what is better, it would be great if we can support concat on arbitrary dimension, which could be done by reshape and slice

Which scenarios are you talking about? SGD or ASGD? I think in no matter
which way the update and the adjustment of learning rate should happen on
server side.
- In distributed SGD, the minibatch will be carved into smaller pieces
  and the update will be performed after gathering all worker’s gradient.
- In distributed ASGD, after each minibatch, the update will happen.

lr_scheduler should not be aware of either case, so the code could remain
the same. I think you could still keep num_batch since in SGD case, the
update is still performed after one minibatch. In either case, one _logical_
minibatch still equals to one update.

I dont understand the second problem you mentioned. Why would two layers
update in different frequency? Is this still valid SGD?
​

one example is the alexnet, it has a few conv layers and three big fullc layers. in order to reduce the communication overhead but still enjoy a small batch size, we can sync & update the conv layers for each batch, while sync the fullc layers for every 10 batches.

Oh i see. This the variable batch size trick in Alex paper. Do we have plan
to implement that?

The latest https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/624 can serve as the orthodox network definitions.

To do network parameters extraction and construction in the opposite direction of https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/tools/caffe_converter/convert_model.py, all you need are [`symbol, arg_params, aux_params = load_checkpoint(prefix, epoch)`](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/model.py) and https://github.com/BVLC/caffe/blob/master/examples/pycaffe/caffenet.py.

Currently, it supports arbitrary dimension concatenation for 2D, 3D and 4D tensor.
@futurely That would be very nice to have.

@HyeonwooNoh's entry in the [PASVOC VOC segmentation](http://host.robots.ox.ac.uk:8080/leaderboard/displaylb.php?challengeid=11&compid=6) benchmark     [POSTECH_DeconvNet_CRF_VOC](http://host.robots.ox.ac.uk:8080/leaderboard/displaylb.php?challengeid=11&compid=6#KEY_POSTECH_DeconvNet_CRF_VOC) achieved 74.8% average precision. In [his implementation](https://github.com/HyeonwooNoh/caffe/commits/new_data_layer), pixel wise classification loss [RedSoftmaxWithLossLayer](RedSoftmaxWithLossLayer), [EltwiseAccuracyLayer](https://github.com/HyeonwooNoh/caffe/blob/new_data_layer/src/caffe/layers/eltwise_accuracy_layer.cpp) and [RedAccuracyLayer](https://github.com/HyeonwooNoh/caffe/blob/new_data_layer/src/caffe/layers/red_accuracy_layer.cpp) are related to segmentation. The C++ [seg data layers](https://github.com/HyeonwooNoh/caffe/blob/master/include/caffe/data_layers.hpp) are better replaced by [Python layers](http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/tutorial/new_op_howto.html) like https://github.com/BVLC/caffe/issues/1698#issuecomment-144269770 and https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/554#issuecomment-156230633 which would be easier to implement.

[1] Hyeonwoo Noh, Seunghoon Hong, Bohyung Han. [Learning Deconvolution Network for Semantic Segmentation](http://cvlab.postech.ac.kr/research/deconvnet/). ICCV 2015.

@futurely 
EltwiseAccuracyLayer is used to compute accuracy for segmentation, but
RedSoftmaxWithLossLayer is not used for segmentation (it's implemented for another purpose).
For segmentation, SoftmaxLoss layer should be refered.

Can you be more specific? i.e, provide a snippet that produces your problem. If you mean directly get element from gpu into a float variable. It is indeed not possible, because the content of that float do not sit on main memory, and the instruction is not aware of that, an explicit copy to CPU is needed

@starimpact The best way to get help is to **_paste something that others can reproduce**_, like a snippet that can be compiled  and produces the warning you mentioned. Otherwise, it is very hard for others to help you, as guessing the context of what might happened on your side, so hard for others to take actions, and reply to your issue.

This warning is quite clear, saying that there is an assignment, and source shape array of the assignment might not be initialized.  This is likely due to for example, shape array of `t_data` or `t_label` are not completely initialized. Check how did you created the `t_data` and `t_label`, if some shape content you used was not initialized.

You need to change the symbol output to get internals. For example for a `FeedForward` model:
In general, the target symbol name is symbol's name plus `_output`

`````` python
# get internals from model's symbol
internals = model.symbol.get_internals()
# get feature layer symbol out of internals
fea_symbol = internals["global_pool_output"]
# Make a new model by using an internal symbol. We can reuse all parameters from model we trained before
# In this case, we must set ```allow_extra_params``` to True
# Because we don't need params from FullyConnected symbol
feature_extractor = mx.model.FeedForward(ctx=mx.gpu(), symbol=fea_symbol, numpy_batch_size=1,
                                         arg_params=model.arg_params, aux_params=model.aux_params,
                                         allow_extra_params=True)
# predict feature
global_pooling_feature = feature_extractor.predict(batch)
print(global_pooling_feature.shape)
``````

If you need several outputs, you can `group` the internals and outputs to form a new symbol, then bind with weight.

Full example can be found at: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/notebooks/predict-with-pretrained-model.ipynb

OK, that's somewhat helpful. Is there an example of the C API used as a C script?

Is that possible to assign different weights to different ground-truth labels? The weight can be set as 1/f_i, where f_i is the frequency of the i-th label in the training set, to deal with the unbalanced number of training samples of different classes.

In "Learning Deconvolution Network for Semantic Segmentation", "for both datasets, we maintain the balance for the number of examples across classes by adding redundant examples for the classes with limited number of examples."

In more [traditional](http://scikit-learn.org/stable/auto_examples/linear_model/plot_sgd_weighted_samples.html) machine learning algorithms, [weighted sample](http://scikit-learn.org/stable/auto_examples/svm/plot_weighted_samples.html) are not unusual. But long tail samples sometimes hurt the performance in DL experiments [2]. It's doubtful whether duplicating them will be of any help.

[2] Erjin Zhou, Zhimin Cao, Qi Yin: Naive-Deep Face Recognition: Touching the Limit of LFW Benchmark or Not? CoRR abs/1501.04690 (2015).
@futurely Please take a look at Eq.(1) of http://www.cv-foundation.org/openaccess/content_cvpr_2015/papers/Mostajabi_Feedforward_Semantic_Segmentation_2015_CVPR_paper.pdf

As you can see on the PASCAL VOC 2012 segmentation [leaderboard](http://host.robots.ox.ac.uk:8080/leaderboard/displaylb.php?challengeid=11&compid=6#KEY_POSTECH_DeconvNet_CRF_VOC), most top performing submissions used the Microsoft COCO dataset to further boost performance. The observation is very similar with what was discovered in "Naive-Deep Face Recognition": big data is more effective than complicated algorithms.

my question is, does a user needs to install `protobuf` to the codes. in other words, does the `xxx.pb.py` requires `protobuf` to run. If not, then it is fine. But if yes, I suggest to 
- only keeps the .proto file while delete the .pb.py file, since the latter varies for different versions of google protobuf
- add a `makefile` which will compile the .pb.py using the protobuf 
- add a readme to tell the users how to install the google protobuf

yes, but the default FeedForward model only support single loss. You'll need to write your own model and solver. Check examples/autoencoder/model.py&solver.py for example.
I think Feedforward already support multiple losses, as long as you group together? At least seems that was the case in julia @pluskid . We might need a toy example for this

Yes! I believe multiple loss in Python is also supported. Something like this:

``` python
loss1 = mx.sym.SoftmaxOutput(data1, name='softmax1')
loss2 = mx.sym.SoftmaxOutput(data2, name='softmax2')

loss_comb = mx.sym.Group(loss1, loss2)

model = FeedForward(loss_comb, ctx=...)
```
Agreed with @pluskid .
